intro: Gayella, commonly known as the rock fig, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Moraceae. It consists of several species, most of which are shrubs or small trees native to southern Africa. The plants are characterized by their simple, alternate leaves and small, clustered flowers that are often green or yellowish in color. The fruit is a small, fleshy drupe that is typically eaten by birds and small mammals, aiding in seed dispersal. Gayella species are often found in rocky or arid environments, showcasing their adaptability to harsh conditions.
